entry.title: Como a Reforma Tributária no Brasil Impacta os usuários SAP
entry.content:
Click here for the english version.

A reforma tributária no Brasil é um tema de grande relevância para empresas que precisam se adaptar a estas mudanças legais. Para os usuários SAP, é importante entender como a reforma afeta os processos logísticos e financeiros, estar ciente dos prazos de implantação e saber quais são as soluções providas pela SAP para garantir uma transição tranquila.

Cronograma de Implementação da Reforma

  • 2026: A reforma tributária começa a ser testada, com taxas iniciais mais baixas de 0,9% para a Contribuição sobre Bens e Serviços (CBS) e 0,1% para o Imposto sobre Bens e Serviços (IBS).
  • 2027: A CBS passa a valer, substituindo PIS e Cofins. A alíquota de IPI será zerada, exceto para produtos industrializados na ZFM.
  • 2028: Último ano de ICMS e ISS sem alteração.
  • 2029: Eliminação gradual do ICMS e ISS, com redução anual de 10% em suas taxas, como parte da substituição pelo IBS.
  • 2033: Adoção integral do novo regime tributário, com a extinção de ICMS e ISS.

Entregas da SAP
A SAP está comprometida em apoiar seus clientes durante a transição para o novo modelo tributário. As soluções SAP estão sendo atualizadas para atender aos novos requisitos legais, garantindo que as empresas possam se adequar às mudanças.

SNOTE: Note Analyzer tool
Recomendamos fortemente o uso da ferramenta Note Analyzer para organizar a implementação das SAP Notes desta solução. Consulte a SAP Note 3200109 para obter instruções sobre essa ferramenta e utilize o arquivo XML anexo à SAP Note 3561376 para relacionar as entregas da SAP para a Reforma Tributária do Brasil. A versão mais recente do Note Analyzer introduz um recurso que exibe a ordem de implementação na coluna "comentários" após a importação do XML. Siga esta ordem, mesmo que algumas SAP Notes não sejam relevantes para o seu negócio. Observe que a ferramenta fornece a ordem correta, mas não uma lista completa dos pré-requisitos das SAP Notes. Assim, análises adicionais podem ser necessárias para lidar com possíveis dependências.

Observações importantes durante a implementação das SAP notes
Para cada nota SAP que será implementada, reserve um momento para ler o seu conteúdo em texto. Desta forma, será possível se informar sobre notas pré-requisito conhecidas, passos manuais a serem executados antes ou depois da implementação automática das instruções de correção, assim como ficar ciente de outras instruções. A leitura do conteúdo de cada nota a ser implementada pode evitar problemas de implementação e a necessidade de retrabalho.
Além disso, é muito importante não prosseguir para a implementação de SAP notes subsequentes deixando notas anteriores incorretamente implementadas no sistema (status incompletely implemented), pois isso leva a um sistema corrompido e sem os contextos e objetos necessários para futuras implementações. Portanto, ao implementar uma lista de SAP Notes, assegure-se de que cada nota está sendo implementada corretamente e completamente.

Recursos de Apoio
A SAP disponibiliza vários recursos de apoio, entre eles:

  • SAP Work Zone - Brazil - Tax Reform Localization: Permite que clientes e parceiros da SAP compartilhem informações e colaborem em assuntos relacionados à Reforma Tributária. Este espaço tem atualização diária.
  • Plataforma Regulatory Change Manager: Anúncios de mudanças legais e planejamento de entregas de soluções.
  • SAP Note 3561376 - Tax Reform Leading SAP Note para leitura: Descreve a estratégia de entrega e suporte para a solução de Reforma Tributária do Brasil. Esta nota, de atualização frequente, lista as entregas da solução conforme são liberadas para clientes. Assim, anexado a ela está o arquivo XML sempre atualizado para o uso no Note Analyzer, auxiliando a implementação das SAP Notes na ordem adequada.
  • SAP Note 3637842 - Brazil Tax Reform - Testing Limitations with SEFAZ para leitura: Esta SAP Note informativa destaca os processos ainda não suportados pela SAP relacionados à Reforma Tributária no Brasil, especialmente sobre cenários a serem testados com a SEFAZ. Esta nota será atualizada regularmente.
  • KBA 3642384 - Brazil Tax Reform Troubleshooting Guide: Além de explicar sobre a entrega da SAP e trazer os links diretos da plataforma Regulatory Change Manager para os assuntos da Reforma Tributária, este KBA de Troubleshooting auxilia a resolver os possíveis problemas já identificados durante a implementação das SAP notes. Ao oferecer soluções para problemas comuns, este KBA é continuamente atualizado para incluir novas informações.

SAP ERP - Help Portal

  • Grupos de impostos e tipos de imposto adicionados à nota fiscal
  • Impostos CBS e IBS como valores estatísticos na nota fiscal
  • Definir situação tributária para CBS e IBS
  • Situação tributária CBS e IBS para vendas
  • Modificações de montante base para CBS e IBS utilizando TAXBRA
  • Ativação de NBS para determinação CBS e IBS em cenários de compras
  • Modificações de montante base para CBS e IBS utilizando o esquema de cálculo TAXBRJ
  • Campos adicionados à nota fiscal para impostos CBS e IBS
  • Cálculo da taxa nominal e textos de nota fiscal para CBS e IBS no Nota Fiscal Writer
  • Modificações de montante base para CBS e IBS utilizando procedimentos de determinação de preços RVABRA e RVXBRA
  • Determinar situação tributária para Business Add In CBS e IBS
  • Campos adicionados para taxas nominais na estrutura de BAdI da nota fiscal
  • Campo adicionado à tabela de nota fiscal para cálculo de imposto IBS
  • Situação tributária CBS e IBS para compras
  • Determinação do imposto ampliada com situação tributária para CBS e IBS para processos de vendas
  • Campos adicionados às estruturas BAdI e BAPIs da nota fiscal
  • Situação tributária CBS e IBS para movimento de mercadorias

SAP S/4HANA - Help Portal

  • Grupos de impostos e tipos de imposto adicionados à nota fiscal
  • Impostos CBS e IBS como valores estatísticos na nota fiscal
  • Definir situação tributária para CBS e IBS
  • Situação tributária CBS e IBS para vendas
  • Modificações de montante base para CBS e IBS utilizando TAXBRA
  • Ativação de NBS para determinação CBS e IBS em cenários de compras
  • Modificações de montante base para CBS e IBS utilizando o esquema de cálculo TAXBRJ
  • Campos adicionados à nota fiscal para impostos CBS e IBS
  • Cálculo da taxa nominal e textos de nota fiscal para CBS e IBS no Nota Fiscal Writer
  • Modificações de montante base para CBS e IBS utilizando procedimentos de determinação de preços RVABRA e RVXBRA
  • Determinar situação tributária para Business Add In CBS e IBS
  • Campos adicionados para taxas nominais na estrutura de BAdI da nota fiscal
  • Campo adicionado à tabela de nota fiscal para cálculo de imposto IBS
  • Situação tributária CBS e IBS para compras
  • Determinação do imposto ampliada com situação tributária para CBS e IBS para processos de vendas
  • Campos adicionados às estruturas BAdI e BAPIs da nota fiscal
  • Situação tributária CBS e IBS para movimento de mercadorias

Prazo de Implementação para clientes
Os clientes SAP precisam ter as soluções SAP referentes à reforma tributária totalmente implementadas e testadas até dezembro de 2025, para garantir conformidade com as novas obrigações a partir de janeiro de 2026.

Validação por parte do governo
Atualmente, é possível testar a aprovação de documentos com os campos dos novos tributos em ambiente de homologação da SEFAZ e, de forma facultativa, enviá-los também em produção.
O ambiente produtivo da SEFAZ começará a validar os novos campos de XML da NF-e relacionados aos impostos da reforma tributária a partir de janeiro de 2026. Até essa data, o preenchimento desses novos campos é facultativo e, mesmo que preenchidos, não devem causar rejeição na aprovação da NF-e.
A partir de janeiro de 2026, o preenchimento dos campos dos novos impostos será obrigatório, com valor jurídico, para documentos fiscais eletrônicos em ambiente de produção. A não conformidade poderá levar à rejeição das notas fiscais.

Conclusão
A reforma tributária no Brasil traz uma mudança legal significativa, portanto, esteja atento ao prazo de adequação.
As notas informativas da SAP listadas acima e o KBA de troubleshooting seguirão em constante atualização para que você tenha acesso a informações relevantes enquanto atualiza o seu sistema.
Utilize os recursos disponíveis e interaja no Work Zone para tirar dúvidas.

entry.title: Unlocking the Power of Model Context Protocol (MCP) for SAP Business Applications
entry.content:
What is Model Context Protocol?

In today’s rapidly evolving enterprise landscape, SAP business applications are at the heart of mission-critical operations—from Order to Cash and Procure to Pay, to Financial Reporting and beyond. Yet, many organizations still face persistent challenges: siloed data, fragmented workflows, and manual processes that slow innovation and limit agility.

Model Context Protocol (MCP) represents a breakthrough in how Generative AI—including Large Language Models (LLMs)—can drive real business outcomes within SAP environments. MCP transforms AI from a passive responder into an active agent, capable of planning, orchestrating, and executing complex business tasks across diverse SAP and non-SAP systems

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) enables any functionality to be exposed as AI-accessible tools, allowing models to not only understand a request but also act to fulfil it.

Born from Anthropic’s work on the Claude Code IDE, MCP was designed to seamlessly integrate a wide range of capabilities — from multi-language programming support to CI/CD frameworks and dependency management — directly into the AI’s operational toolkit. Instead of retraining models for every new capability, MCP gives them instant access to the tools they need.

Unlike Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), which focuses on providing extra context to the model, MCP goes further — it provides actionable functionality. When combined, RAG and MCP form a powerful framework: RAG informs the AI with relevant knowledge, while MCP equips it with the means to execute tasks.

This synergy enables AI to plan, select the right tools, and carry out complex operations — paving the way for true agentic applications in enterprise environments. For SAP business applications, MCP is not just an enhancement — it’s the future of how AI will work with systems to drive automation, decision-making, and innovation.

How MCP works?

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) operates on client–server architecture model that transforms Large Language Models (LLMs) from passive responders into active agents capable of executing complex business tasks. On the server side, MCP hosts a library of well-defined tools — each with clear input/output specifications — that can securely access data, run processes, and return results. These servers can run locally for tasks that don’t require cloud services, or be securely hosted to connect with databases, SAP systems, and other enterprise platforms. On the client side, the MCP client acts as the bridge between the LLM and the server: it injects the right context from the user request, discovers available tools via frameworks like LangGraph, and enables the LLM to plan, select, and invoke the appropriate tool. The results are fed back to the LLM, which then produces a polished, context-aware response for the user. By connecting to multiple MCP servers, applications can tap into diverse capabilities across domains — enabling true agentic intelligence where AI autonomously plans, executes, and delivers business outcomes.

Key capabilities of MCP:

 

How is it Applicable to SAP Business Applications

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) has strong applicability to SAP business applications when viewed from both a business and technical perspective.

From a business perspective, SAP applications support complex, end-to-end scenarios across multiple lines of business such as Order to Cash, Procure to Pay, Hire to Retire, Materials Planning, and Financial Reporting and many more. Each of these high-level process drills down further into granular Level 2 and Level 3 processes, where specific operational steps occur. On a client landscape, the data for these processes might exist on different SAP or non-SAP systems. This poses a problem to the end-to-end process flows as this data is siloed and difficult to access.

The MCP tools can be designed to align directly with these sub-processes existing on multiple systems, enabling agentic AI clients to interpret a user’s request, extract relevant context using the tools, plan the necessary sequence of actions, and then invoke the right tools to perform operations on SAP systems. This means that tasks which traditionally require manual navigation through multiple SAP transactions can now be automated, orchestrated, and executed intelligently by AI.

 

From a technical perspective, SAP ecosystem offers cloud-native capabilities via SAP BTP and Kyma, which can host and run MCP servers with well-defined tools. An MCP client could, for example, can be implemented as a lightweight Flask application with multiple API routes, each tailored for specific user requests. When a request comes in, the client extracts the context, passes it to the LLM, and the LLM determines the required actions before calling the appropriate MCP server tools. This client application can be deployed on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry and integrated with a CAP application, complete with a user interface — such as BPA forms or interactive UI apps — to give end users a seamless working environment or integrated with Joule Studio

In essence, MCP server and client mechanisms can function as microservices that integrate effortlessly with SAP applications on SAP BTP, enabling:

  • Direct alignment of MCP tools with SAP Level 2 and Level 3 processes.
  • Secure execution of business logic via SAP ODATA services and BTP-hosted MCP servers bringing in data from other Applications into SAP.
  • Context-aware orchestration of actions by LLMs, reducing manual intervention.

By combining SAP’s robust business processes with MCP’s agentic capabilities, enterprises can move toward a future where SAP applications are not only transactional but also intelligent, autonomous, and proactive in delivering business outcomes.

Example implementation

Consider a comprehensive Vendor Onboarding scenario — one that not only creates vendors in the SAP system but also validates their details via multiple external APIs, retrieves information from various sources, identifies missing data, generates a targeted questionnaire, and sends it to the vendor contact for completion.

Traditionally, this process takes several days and involves multiple teams working across different systems to collect, verify, and enter vendor details into SAP. Using Large Language Models (LLMs) combined with MCP servers and tools, this workflow can be transformed into Agentic Automation — where AI autonomously plans and executes the onboarding steps based on the specific vendor’s context. The automation adapts dynamically to each case, using available information and determining what needs to be collected, drastically reducing onboarding time while leveraging existing tools in the customer’s landscape.

In the recent SAP–AWS Hack2Build event, IBM implemented an agentic Sustainability skills using MCP server–client architecture using SAP BTP and AWS joint reference architecture as follows:

  1. API Availability: The necessary Sustainability Tracing APIs were already built and exposed via AWS API Gateway.
  2. MCP Server Setup: An MCP server was created to expose these AWS APIs, making them directly callable by the LLM. Without MCP, the APIs could only be used by other applications or services — not directly by AI agents.
  3. Hosting on SAP BTP: The MCP server was deployed and run on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, ensuring secure and scalable access.
  4. MCP Client Application: A lightweight HTTP-routes-based MCP client was built to handle natural language queries from end users.
    • The client extracts context and parameters from the user request using the LLM.
    • It calls the LLM with the relevant tools and parameters so the AI can decide when to use a tool — and when not to, in case of a generic question.
    • This client was also hosted on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry and connected to the MCP server to list and use tools dynamically based on the request.
  5. CAP Application Integration: A CAP (Cloud Application Programming) application was used as the frontend/UI layer, sending the user’s request to the MCP client and displaying results back to the user.

By simply using the MCP server and client framework hosted on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, we built an end-to-end agentic application. This approach not only integrates external APIs directly into the SAP landscape but also provides a scalable pattern to make existing SAP applications agentic — enabling them to autonomously plan, execute, and adapt workflows.

 

 

Business Value and Benefits

Effective Agentic Automation is becoming one of the most impactful approaches to enterprise process automation, offering strategic and operational advantages across SAP landscapes. Traditionally, automation initiatives have focused on the “happy path” — the ideal scenario where processes execute exactly as planned. However, large organizations experience happy paths only about 40% of the time. The remaining majority are exceptions caused by regional variations, departmental workflows, process differences, compliance requirements, or unforeseen data gaps.

This is exactly where the Model Context Protocol (MCP) integrated with SAP business applications delivers transformative value. Rather than relying on rigid, rule-based flows, MCP enables agentic systems that adapt to context in real time. LLM-powered MCP clients can understand nuanced user requests, identify what information is available, determine what is missing, plan next steps dynamically, and call the right tools to complete the process — whether the scenario follows the happy path or not.

Applied to SAP, this means:

  • End-to-end process automation for complex scenarios like Vendor Onboarding, Order to Cash, or Procure to Pay, without manual form-filling or multiple transaction hops, and integrating external tools within SAP workflows.
  • Adaptive workflows that can continue operating despite ambiguity, incomplete data, or process deviations.
  • Human oversight with reduced workload, where operators monitor progress and guide agents in exceptional cases, rather than executing every step themselves.
  • Integration of external APIs and internal services, bringing together SAP ODATA services, SAP BTP microservices, and third-party tools under a single agentic control layer.

By hosting MCP servers and clients on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, organizations can make existing SAP applications truly agentic — systems that don’t just respond to requests but can plan, decide, and act in pursuit of business goals. The result is a significant reduction in process cycle times, improved operational efficiency, and greater flexibility in handling real-world complexity.

In short, MCP brings the intelligence and adaptability needed to turn SAP into a proactive business partner — one that can automate not just the ideal scenarios, but also the messy, exception-driven realities that dominate enterprise operations.

Things to look out for

While the Model Context Protocol (MCP) offers powerful capabilities to make SAP applications agentic, there are several critical considerations that must be addressed to ensure secure, reliable, and scalable deployments:

  1. Security of Applications – MCP servers and clients can be hosted across different environments, and tools may need to access data from multiple sources. This distributed nature requires end-to-end security planning, including authentication, authorization, encryption, and secure API access. Role propagation across systems is essential so that permissions are consistently enforced throughout the workflow.
  2. Context Engineering – The quality and precision of context passed to the LLM directly determines which tools are invoked and in what sequence. Poorly defined context can lead to incorrect tool calls or inefficient workflows. Each use case may require careful context design and parameter mapping to ensure the LLM receives exactly the right inputs for optimal execution. This often requires iterative refinement during testing and rollout.
  3. Performance & Scalability – MCP-enabled workflows can involve multiple tool calls, external API requests, and data processing steps. In high-volume SAP environments, this can introduce latency if not optimized. It’s important to design for efficient tool execution, minimize unnecessary calls, cache frequently accessed data where appropriate, and ensure the MCP server infrastructure is scalable to handle concurrent requests without impacting business SLAs. Monitoring and load testing should be part of the deployment strategy.

Conclusion

The MCP Server and Client framework has the potential to transform SAP applications into truly agentic systems. By using tools exposed through MCP servers — and seamlessly integrating them with SAP BTP we can have a variety of tools that bring extensive functionality to Generative AI models — enterprises can unlock a new level of intelligent automation. With the ability to reason, plan, and decide the next steps in a process, AI agents can autonomously execute workflows while still operating under human oversight. This ensures that productivity and efficiency gains are not only substantial but also practical and measurable, delivering real business impact.

Why invest in MCP now?

As AI becomes central to enterprise strategy, MCP unlocks the potential for SAP applications to become truly intelligent, autonomous, and proactive partners in business success. By bridging the gap between AI reasoning and enterprise action, MCP empowers leaders to realize tangible ROI, accelerate innovation, and future-proof their SAP investments.

To learn more, do meet us at SAP TechEd, AWS Re:Invent or connect with us via LinkedIn.

entry.title: Seeking Guidance on Configuring Access for Vendor Transactions in S4HANA Public Cloud System
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We have four users with specific roles and restrictions:

User A:
- Can post entries for a specific vendor.
- Needs access to all postings and reports related to that vendor.

User B:
- No access to any data related to the vendor managed by User A.

User C:
- Can make payments for all vendors except the one managed by User A.
- Vendor managed by User A should not be visible in any payment applications.

User 😧
- Can make payments only for the vendor managed by User A.

Applications in use include:
- Maintain Business Partner
- Create Supplier Invoice Advance
- Manage Supplier Line Item
- Display Supplier Balance
- Manage Automatic Payment
- Display Journal Entries (with respect to vendor)
- Supplier Down Payment
- Post Outgoing Payment

Could you please suggest ways to configure these settings and meet the requirements?

entry.title: Re: Master Logistics Series :Outbound Logistics with SAP Logistics Management-Direct LTL Variant
entry.content:
Hi @Bimal_S ,

Thanks for the comment .

This is not an IM Storage location , it is a storage location that is tied to a warehouse .In S/4 ,LGM warehouse is considered as third party decentralized warehouse .

Follow these steps :

  1. Define a storage location under Enterprise Structure >Definition  Materials Management -> Maintain Storage Location.

  2. Define a warehouse number under Enterprise Structure > Definition  Logistics Execution > Define Warehouse Number.

  3. Assign the warehouse number to the storage location under Enterprise Structure  >Assignment  Logistics Execution > Assign Warehouse Number to Plant and Storage Location.

  4. Under Logistics Execution  Integration of External Warehouse Systems  >Activate Decentralized Warehouse System, activate the warehouse as a third-party warehouse by the following settings:

    • Selecting External WMS

    • Choosing SOAP Web Services for Communication External WM

    • Choosing Distribution Immediately at Document Creation for Dist. Mode for the Delivery

entry.title: Content Agent now supports modifiable Transport Request
entry.content:
Overview

With the latest release of SAP Content Agent, you can export the development changes from SAP BTP services such as SAP Integration Suite,  Role Collections etc, to an existing modifiable transport request created in SAP Cloud Transport Management Service. You can also choose to create a new Transport Request and select the option to keep it "modifiable". 

This feature would help the users to collect all related changes and iterative changes into single transport request which makes it more manageable to review and process the requests.

Try it out!

  1. Launch the Content Agent UI from your development account by subscribing to the "free" plan and assign the required "Content Agent Export Operator" or "Content Agent Admin" role collection to your user.
    See Subscribe the UI plan and Assign User Roles and Permissions.
  2.  Launch the UI, and navigate to Content Types page. Check the status of the content type that you wish to export and if it is inactive, use the automation feature.
    See the details as described here: Automated Integration in SAP Content Agent to enable BTP services for transport 

  3. Navigate to Export page and use the wizard steps to select and export content.
    There are two options provided to you. 
    a)  You can choose Create a New Transport Request option if you want to create a new request in Cloud Transport Management. You can Select the checkbox Keep this Transport Request modifiable if you want to append content later to this transport request.  

     b) Choose Existing Transport Request presents the input box to type in the Transport Request Id. The UI also provides the option to view the list of existing modifiable Transport Request ID along with description and source node. This would append the content bundled as MTAR into the existing Transport Request in Cloud Transport Management. 


  4. Proceed to the next step in the wizard which triggers an asynchronous process. Once completed, you can check the Activities Performed page for more details.

  5. Navigate to the Cloud Transport Management UI to view the complete details of transport Request status. 

     

Summary

Use the feature from Content Agent UI enabling the creation and changes to modifiable transport request towards your SAP Cloud Changes. 
For more details on managing modifiable transport requests, refer to https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/modifiable-transport-requests-now-also-for-your-sap-cloud-changes/ba-p/14194823 .

entry.title: Re: Add screen text field dynamically
entry.content:
Hi,

that’s a limitation of classic Dynpro. Screens are statically compiled, so you cannot really add new fields at runtime. What MB1A does is show more rows in a table control, not new fields. If you need truly dynamic behavior, you should look into SAPUI5 or Fiori where UI elements can be created or hidden based on user actions or data.

Cheers,
Sebastian

A customer has a potential project where they need to split one current company code into two (e.g. moving part of activity in one company code to another for on-going operations).  Some consulting firms say they can copy plants, sales orgs and purchasing orgs from one company to another vs. creating net new plants, sales orgs, etc.  This would save time and effort, but will this cause issues in the future?  Does this align with SAP's guidance and overall recommendation?  SAP Note 1595808 seems to advise against this.  Other thoughts would be appreciated.

entry.title: Re: Requirement is to restrict Unblock payment tab in man...
entry.content:
Good day @sandeep_shankarampet 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

Manage Automatic Payments, Business Role - Restriction Entity, Financing Order Processing, SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Customer Payments, Manage Payment Blocks

In public cloud edition, you can control both “Block for Payment” and Unblock for Payment” by the same authorisation object (Authorization Group for Journal Entry Document Type). However, these two actions cannot be separated directly through these restrictions alone, reason is, SAP delivers them as part of the same Business Catalog permissions under Accounts Payable or Accounts Receivable roles. That means:

  • When you remove the Authorization Group restriction, you are blocking access to both processes.
  • When you reassign it, the system restores access to both actions.

I recommend taking a clean-core adherent approach to achieve your business requirement by allowing Block for Payment while restricting Unblock for Payment.

 

First, you need to identify the existing business role. Go to Maintain Business Roles app.

Locate the role that currently allow both actions (as an example, the screenshot below references BR_AP_ACCOUNTANT)

Copy the role that allows both actions

Use a Copy Role and name it as you deem fit and save (For reference purpose I have used ZBR_AP_BLOCK_ONLY in the screenshot)

In the new role, remove FIN_BC_AP_UNBLOCK_PC and keep only FIN_BC_AP_BLOCK_PC. These catalogs correspond to the Block for Payment and Unblock for Payment and save.

Users assigned to the new role can open “Block for Payment” but cannot access the “Unblock for Payment” app. Thereafter, assign the new role to the specific users who should have Block only authorisation and save.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

The error indicates that you are trying to migrate document info records that contain URLs, but your current repository configuration is not aligned with the Cloud Foundry environment requirements. Please review this SAP Note for the set-up guide as the resolution: 3132224 - DIR and File Migration Guide for SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Duong

entry.title: Preference Management in GTS e4H for Intercompany Sales scenario
entry.content:
Hello Gurus

I would like to know what is the standard process for issuing vendor declaration to end customer,  in case Intercompany sales scenario:

There are 2 sales organisations : A  and B (2 distinct companies) - B creates sales order to end customer and A produces and delivers goods to end customer. 

There are 2 invoices:

1. Inter-company invoice between A and B. 

2. End customer invoice from B to end customer. 

Both the invoices have plant of the producing company A. (Also, the outbound delivery has the plant code of company A) 

Issues/Questions

1. What is SAP Standard and who is legally authorised to issue vendor declaration to end customer? - Company A, who has the preference data of the product or company B who issues invoice (and has sales order) to end customer? 

2. Since plant is used to determine the administrative unit in GTS, both the invoices land into the same Administrative Unit of company A. However our business requirement is that company B should issue LTSD to customer as it has the "sales contract" with the customer.  But since A has the prefect result of the product, LTSDs need to be exchanged between A and B. 

I would like to know what is SAP standard in case of Intercompany Sales. 

Thanks for the help in advance, 

S

entry.title: S/4 HANA TM: Basic vs Advance- Deciding Factors & Your Strategy
entry.content:
<Note : Article has referred SAP Note 3065464>

Basic TM: More Power Under the Hood Than You Think

Don't underestimate the Basic Transportation Management (TM) license. Many assume it only handles simple, straight-line shipments, leading them to overlook its true value. In fact, Basic TM offers a robust foundation for complex logistics right out of the box.

You might be surprised by what's included without needing the Advanced license:

  • Complex Route Planning is fully supported. Basic TM handles both multi-pick and multi-drop scenarios for both incoming (inbound) and outgoing (outbound) deliveries.
  • The Critical Restriction: The only key limitation is that you cannot combine Freight Units from inbound and outbound deliveries onto the same Freight Order.
  • Core Execution and Settlement: It supports FSD creation , and generating PO/Service entry sheets.
  • GIS Integration: Direct external GIS hooks for geo-coordinates, distances, and durations—Basic only, no Advanced needed.
  • Unified Package Building (UPB): Auto-building via Packaging Specifications (PS) or Packing Instructions (PI)—basic supports.

A Single Process Step Can Trigger an Advanced License

Nuance is king. The line is indeed "pretty-thin," often hinging on one config or data choice. ( Refre SAP Note 3065464 )

  • Freight Unit Creation: Basic  supports deliveries only. Advanced required for direct from sales/purchase/stock transfer orders (early planning).
  • Freight Rate Tables: Basic limits to 3 scales/dimensions; 4+ scales need Advanced for granularity. Again it does not fullfill many customers wish list but a smart consultant can suggest alternative by following same restriction.
  • Charge Calculation: Be careful many calculation bases can not be used like: Holiday charges etc.
  • Schedules: Basic allows Schedules master data, but "cut-off dates" (e.g., for time windows) are Advanced-only.
  • Resource Management: Basic permits simple "Active Vehicle" in Freight Orders; full Resource objects (vehicles, trailers, drivers) are Advanced. This is really disappointing as my per my experience, it gives lot of pain while suggesting alternatives to client  to manage that .
  • Freight Forwarding: All core capabilities designed for LSPs are Advanced-only. This includes managing Forwarding Orders, Agreements, Settlements, and using Strategic Freight Procurement.
  • Modern Carrier Collaboration: The dedicated suite of Fiori apps for working directly with carriers—covering tendering, order confirmation, execution, and settlement—all require the Advanced TM license

Key Points: The Technical Traps

  • TM-EWM Integration (Advanced Shipping & Receiving - ASR):

Basic TM is allowed only if TM and EWM are embedded within the same S/4HANA system.If you deploy TM or EWM on a separate, decentralized server, the exact same integration instantly demands an Advanced TM license.

  • Side-by-Side Deployments:

The rule is strict: Any standard side-by-side deployment of S/4HANA TM with any other ERP system (ECC, another S/4HANA instance, or a third-party ERP) requires the Advanced TM license.

The exact same business process—integrating TM with an EWM warehouse—can be covered by your Basic license or require a costly Advanced license, based entirely on whether the systems are on the same server or different ones.

JUST THINK: A technical design decision, made without considering licensing knowledge, can lead to multi-million dollar software costs, even when the business process itself is simple.

 

Conclusion: Plan Before You Suggest your client

Choosing between Basic and Advanced Transportation Management is not a simple menu selection; it is a strategic decision that demands a meticulous review of your

  • end-to-end business processes,
  • charge calculation methodologies, 
  • long-term IT landscape strategy.

The line between the two is filled with subtleties that can be easily missed, and the wrong assumption can lead to unplanned costs or functional gaps down the road.

Before you make a final decision, you must map your non-negotiable business requirements against the detailed feature list, go through the notes.

Please share your experience – what strategies you applied during your implementation while being on Basic License.

entry.title: Re: Unlocking the Power of Model Context Protocol (MCP) for SAP Business Applications
entry.content: The MCP client-server framework provides a powerful and standardized way to integrate external application data into SAP. By exposing external APIs as MCP tools, these capabilities become directly accessible through Joule. This enables users to query, interact with, and take actions on external systems from within SAP, while leveraging SAP BTP for secure, scalable connectivity. The approach streamlines data access, eliminates silos, and empowers users with real-time insights and actions without leaving the SAP environment. This blog is a great pre TechEd read and  has pushed the boundary of what an inbound MCP can do within the SAP landscape.  Hack2Build has become a true incubator for innovation—and the power of three (AWS, IBM, and SAP) shows what it takes to "Be the 5%" that truly succeed with AI.

entry.title: Re: We want to copy serial number from service order item to sales order item.
entry.content:
Hi, Try using Use the enhancement spot ES_CRM_SALES_FWD_EXCHANGE (BAdI CRM_SALES_FWD_EXCHANGE) to intercept the Sales Order creation from Service Order process.

In the BAdI implementation, method IF_EX_CRM_SALES_FWD_EXCHANGE~CHANGE_ITEM_DATA can be used to:

Read the service order item serials from table OBJK / SER02 via OBJECT_GUID or HANDLE.

Pass serial numbers into the sales order item data structure (IT_ITEM_DATA) before commit.

If using SERNR_ADD_TO_AU, call it after the item GUID is available, inside this BAdI, to ensure linkage in SER02 is done correctly.

Debug class **CL_CRMS4_PROC_SALESDOC_FWD → method CREATE_DOC_FROM_SOURCE** to identify when items are transferred - place a breakpoint before CALL FUNCTION 'CRM_ORDER_MAINTAIN'`. ( Try other similar classes and you might find one relevant to your scenario)

entry.title: On-Premise Business AI Infrastructure for Small and Medium Enterprises Using NVIDIA DGX Spark
entry.content:
Disclaimer: this article is written without Generative AI, even for the proof reading 😊 Enjoy the article written by human that is not common nowadays

Why Business AI?

That is what we always must start with. The business case should go first, for sure, and then we should evaluate possible deployment options, costs and security.

Statistics says that 95% of Generative AI implementations failed and that really scares the market in SAP enterprise software domain as well.

But let’s be honest, we are trying to sell Business AI anywhere as technology, forgetting about the customers, their uniqueness and their current pain points.

At Skybuffer starting from February 2025 (during the last 9 months) we have talked to more than 250 customers of different sizes presenting them Business AI technologies and discussing their use cases, or better to say helping them to find how Business AI can help their employees and partners to automate company’s workflows.

There are three main groups of use cases, as we see it now:

  • Direct interaction with SAP backend system via corporate messengers that brings simplicity and mobility at the same time. In many cases Creating or Updating data in SAP from mobile phones or via Teams brings real value.
  • Converting any unstructured data to knowledge, like SharePoint sources, attachments in SAP, support tickets. Mixing those things together, in different document original languages create real value for employees providing them access to the data that is hidden in most of the organizations.
  • Capacity heavy activities delivered by AI agents, especially helpful with emails data analysis, where the main data is always in attachments. Sometimes it requires to utilize OCR extracting data from scanned PDFs in those scenarios. Some excellent examples are processing vendors emails and posting invoice or service entry sheets into SAP or receiving emails from customers converting their external purchasing data to sales orders.

That is why SAP customers with any SAP backend system, either SAP ECC or S/4HANA, can implement Business AI today. I am not saying that it covers the entire Business AI implementation benefits, however, that is what we are focusing on now and helping SAP customers to allocate the benefits of using the technology.

Costs

In our opinion, Business AI is close to being the tool that must be deployed inside IT infrastructure, but a technology that is to being considered only if it returns the investment. Think about the indirect impact of missing Business AI in your business landscape. For example, consider the costs of hiring new staff because your employees are moving to other companies that utilize modern technologies. Why should they move? Obvious, because of the same reason we are all talking about Generative AI – to stay competitive on the market.

However, costs of AI must be assessed carefully, because in most of the architecture approaches Business AI is a consumption-based solution. Risky, isn’t it? Of course! Consumption is hard to estimate, and it is also hard to avoid picks, so budgets of Business AI productive usage might be unacceptably high compared to the potential savings the technology brings. That is why we built Skybuffer AI as a solution with the double deployment options:

  • On premise, there is a clear and 100% predictable TCO.
  • On SAP BTP, this is a great option for CPEA contracts, for example, because in this case Business AI consumes the credits that are already paid, and we avoid extra costs for the infrastructure.

Why is DGX Spark in the article name?

Well, DGX Spark here is not because it is a buzz word now, for sure. That is because DGX Spark provides an excellent opportunity for small and medium enterprises to bring 15x15x12 cm GPU-unit to support their Business AI operations for a very compatible price. Actually, it allows us to keep both compute-unit and GPU-unit in the network avoiding data leakage and consumption-based costs. Excellent? Of course!

Here is how we use it deploying Skybuffer AI on premise:

Figure 01. Skybuffer AI deployment with GPU-unit served by DGX Spark

Criticism?

Yes, even writing this article I am already hearing the criticism 😊 Guessing the comments like, “that is not for productive environment”, “DGX Spark tokens generation too low to serve even Small businesses” and many other sharp negatives. But let’s move back to the beginning of the article and understand the reason why I’ve spent so much time talking about use cases first. Yes, now it is obvious that many mentioned use cases can be addressed by DGX Spark working as GPU-unit. Example? Easy!

Example #1: Vendor emails processing with data posting into SAP backend and saving originals (files) into the DMS (like SharePoint, Join, Google or whatever DMS is in use).

In the architecture mentioned above, Skybuffer AI allows almost out of the box creation of an AI Agent that will check, for example, Account Payable mailbox, read emails, analyze attachments, move them to DMS and create financial postings in SAP backend saving links to the attachments in DMS (either external or internal SAP DMS) on the SAP financial document level. In scenario, if we schedule the agent carefully, it can work in the almost synchronous 24/7 mode.

In case we schedule the Vendor Emails processing AI Agent with the limit to process just one vendor email in the minute, we will avoid pick system loads, and in this case, we can keep AI agent active 24/7. In such deployment it will be able to process 1 440 emails and create postings in SAP a day, that gives us 43 200 a month and amazing number of 518 400 documents a year!! All powered by one DGX Spark GPU-unit keeping the data on premise and avoiding cloud consumption.

That is what we call a proper deployment of Business AI. And Small and Medium businesses do not usually have such big number of documents from vendors, even the Cirque du Soleil does not have according to the latest SAP news post 😊 What we usually do, we add extra Business AI scenarios to be processed by the same Skybuffer AI deployment.

Example #2: Automation of SAP user management services

Small and Medium businesses do use password-based login to SAP backend, so users keep locking themselves or forgetting their passwords. Do we need a powerful GPU-unit with the full size LLM to automate this? No, for sure. We can add those business scenarios to the AI Agent that is processing Vendor Emails 😊

Example #3: Bank data reconciliation

The same setup can be used to assist financial department to match bank transactions to the billing documents in SAP and post accruals for the cases that could not be reconciled, for example, those that miss billing data in SAP that is not created just because someone has forgotten to enter it or integration interfaces have data processing issues. DGX Spark GPU-unit provides particularly good enough capacity here as well.

Those are just a few examples that wind away the skepticism about the utilization of DGX Spark in productive environment.

Is it safe to invest in the on-premise Business AI setup?

If you need full control over costs and data security, the answer is yes. And we think that the answer is yes in general, because Skybuffer AI dual deployment capabilities gives companies the guarantee that on premise Business AI investment can follow their potential future cloud strategy. I am writing and hearing again “what is this crazy man talking about! On premise investment can follow cloud strategies?? That is a paradox!”. And again, the answer is No, of course there is no paradox! If we look at the deployment of Skybuffer AI with integration with SAP Joule:

 Figure 02: Skybuffer AI deployment in SAP BTP with integration with SAP Joule

That is what we call real flexibility!

Sounds like a Gap Closing Solution?

Yes, that is the conclusion we have. There no hard choice anymore to run Business AI on premise or on SAP BTP, no prerequisites to start using Business AI, because the deployment in this article works with SAP ECC (down to 7.01 and even below), SAP S/4HANA on premise or SAP S/4HANA in private cloud. The only question must be asked, when we are talking about Business AI, is about the scenario the company should start with? You’ve seen in our examples that Business AI deployments might bring benefits working in the scenarios that are independent from the historical data you have in your SAP backend and the historical data quality (sometimes it is called data silos), or scenarios that are independent from the version of your system and the point in time of your current digital journey. No need to wait for the upgrades, migrations, or other activities that sound like an act of catching a tail 😊. Just allocate some budget for Business AI deployment, for example, on-premise deployment on DGX Spark that is very affordable, and get the positive feedback from your employees or business partners and enjoy your business workflows simplifications.

entry.title: Re: Capacity Scheduling Tables in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Publi...
entry.content:
Hello @nicolasduches 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

Capacity Scheduling Table, App Extensibility: Capacity Scheduling Table

To summarise, in public cloud edition, the capacity scheduling table dynamically determines the dispatching date range based on your factory calendar, work center operating times, and current system time zone. The reason you cannot select “today” in the date range picker is due to how the system enforces capacity dispatching rules, specifically, the Start of Scheduling Interval” logic that prevents retroactive or mid-shift dispatch.

You can enable same-day dispatch by:

  1. Extending your work center capacity validity to cover the full day.
  2. Confirm your factory calendar marks today as a working day.
  3. Alternatively, you can use the Dispatch from Current Time function.

If you frequently need to dispatch same day operation, I recommend adjusting work center capacity start time. Below is a clean core approach:

Open Manage Work Center app --> Search for your work center

In the search bar, enter the work center ID (e.g., PACK01) --> Go. Select your desired work center from the results list.

Open the capacities tab, here you will find the configuration that controls the valid operating intervals and working time parameters.

Review or adjust the capacity interval. Look for your capacity category --> click the entry to view detailed data. Make sure start time is not later than current system time. Factory Calendar does not mark today as non-working day. Note if the start time = 07:00 and your system time = 16:00, the app considers the shift already in progress and blocks same day dispatch.

If your business wants to allow scheduling any time during the day (for example, 24-hour operation), then your start time = 00:00:00, End Time: 23: 59:00. Keep Length of breaks as 01:00:00 or adjust as needed. Save your changes. This ensures your capacity covers the entire day, so the system will now treat today as open and selectable in the scheduling date range.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Project System for ETO project scenario
entry.content:
Hello SAP experts,

I'm studying for a future implementation the ETO scenario for complex projects using project system. I've read many sap materials from community, help portal and so on but i have still some doubts about the process, specifically the end of the process. I will use the sap standard example of the assembly of a turbine.

I have understood the initial processes of activities scheduling, purchasing of external materials, internal production. Now my doubts are about the last step of the process, the final assembly of the product.

The example of the turbine states that: "In this process it is presumed that the turbine is assembled in the plant."    So I would expect that either:

  • The turbine gets producted by a production order in sap PP.
  • The turbine gets producted by a network activity with a negative requirement (if we do not have/want PP master data such as routing, BOM and so on)

Otherwise i would expect that we should do deliveries from project to the customer's site for the assemblies required by turbine, and having an activity for assembling them at customer site (without tracking the material quantity flow in the system).

None of these is mentioned here, and also in other sap materials I have never understood this last part of the ETO process. 

Am I missing something about how the system should track these last activities of the process? 

 

Any suggestions or clarifications is appreciated! Thank you for your time

entry.title: Re: SAP S4/HANA Cloud Public J78 Cash Flow reconciliation
entry.content:
Hello There,

you could check this note which explains the necessary settings needed for intraday memo records to be create - 3522478.

Use App Define Bank Account Settings - Bank Statements (App ID: F5488)

With this app, you define settings for integrating electronic bank statements with cash management at bank-account level. You define how bank statement data is consumed by cash management, and whether posting is needed after bank statements are imported.

In the configuration activity "Define Planning Levels for Bank Statements", define the derivation logic for memo record types.

 

and then try to upload the intraday bank statement again.

Best Regards

I will use the sap example of assembly of a turbine.

I've understood the initial processes of activities scheduling, purchasing external materials and production of internal materials, but i do not understand how the final assembly of the turbine is done.

  • The material is produced by a network activity with negative requirement (if we do not want/have PP master data such as BOM, routing) and the deliver it to customer

Otherwise, if the assembly happens outside of our plant, i would expect the deliveries from project to customer's site for the assemblies required by the turbine, and then an network activity for assembling them (without tracking in the system the material quantity flow of the turbine).

None of these is mentioned in the example.

entry.title: Re: Is the billing document type for return orders relate...
entry.content:
Good day @suyoung_choi3 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

Credit/Debit Memo - Create for Self-Billing, Customer Returns, Claims, Returns, and Refund Management,

To summarise, the fundamental approach SAP introduced for the public cloud is to keep the core clean. Which also explains why in public cloud SAP uses a single billing type (G2) for all credit transactions to customers. The system distinguishes between goods-related return and value-only credits through the preceding document, item category, and reference flow, not through different billing types. The goal for this approach is to support a clean, standardized, and finance-aligned billing architecture, which is consistent with the clean core strategy.

A glimpse at the E2E process also clarifies this. For the Return Order (with goods movement) it is, Return Order à Return Delivery à Goods Movement à Billing Document (G2) à Accounting: Credit Customer + Reverse COGS

Whilst Credit Memo (without goods movement) is, Credit Memo Request à Billing Document (G2) à Accounting: Credit Customer + Adjust Revenue

Both result in a credit to the customer, but the document flow and accounting impact differ.

Technically, it means:

  • Both documents post to accounts receivable (credit customer) and reverse revenue/COGS depending on the process.
  • SAP standardises the accounting interface by keeping one credit billing type (G2) to simplify integration across Finance, Revenue Accounting, and Returns Management.
  • You cannot create new billing types in public cloud, instead, using the same billing type with different sales document types and item categorises for clarity and consistency.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: The Unified Commerce Mandate: Leveraging SAP Technology to Achieve the 89% Retention Advantage
entry.content:
The era of multi-channel is over. Today's successful businesses rely on a connected SAP Intelligent Enterprise to eliminate friction and drive superior customer lifetime value (CLV).

 

Introduction: The Shift from Silo to System

The term "omni-channel" has long been synonymous with digital ambition, but its true significance has evolved. It is no longer a future-state strategy; it is a fundamental requirement of the Experience Economy. When a modern consumer engages with a brand, they expect a single, continuous conversation, regardless of whether the touchpoint is digital, physical, or voice.

This expectation is directly tied to business outcomes:

  • Customer Loyalty: Research indicates that enterprises with mature omni-channel engagement strategies achieve nearly 89% higher year-over-year customer retention rates compared to those with weak strategies. This loyalty directly translates to a 30% higher customer lifetime value (CLV).

  • Revenue Generation: Campaign performance also reflects this cohesion, with multi-channel campaigns resulting in a purchase rate increase of up to 287%. Furthermore, even traditional retail benefits, as digital omni-channel activity drives an approximate 80% increase in incremental visits to physical store locations.

The challenge, therefore, is structural: how do organisations consolidate disparate customer engagement systems and transactional data into one unified commerce platform?

The Solution Architecture: A Blueprint for Unified Commerce

Achieving this level of consistency requires a robust, scalable architecture that places the customer at the centre, integrating front-end engagement with back-end operations. This is the sweet spot of the SAP Intelligent Enterprise.

A. The Engagement Hub: SAP Commerce Cloud

SAP Commerce Cloud serves as the agile, API-first foundation for customer interaction. Its core strength is the ability to decouple the commerce engine from any single front-end presentation.

  • Headless Flexibility: This architecture allows businesses to quickly deploy commerce services to emerging channels (social, IoT, in-store screens) while ensuring that catalog, inventory, and pricing data remain consistent and centrally managed.

  • Fulfilment Optimisation: It is essential for enabling complex but critical omni-channel services such as Buy Online, Pick Up In-Store (BOPIS) and Ship-from-Store, which demand real-time synchronisation with logistics.

B. The Foundational Core: SAP Business Suite

Flawless omni-channel execution rests on accurate back-office data. SAP S/4HANA (the central pillar of the SAP Business Suite) provides the real-time, consolidated transactional system necessary for this execution.

  • By unifying financial, inventory, and supply chain data, S/4HANA guarantees that the inventory status shown to the customer on Commerce Cloud is instantly reflected across the enterprise, eliminating costly discrepancies and service failures.

C. The Integration & Extension Layer: SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)

The SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) is the critical middleware that eliminates data silos between the Commerce Cloud and the SAP S/4HANA core.

  • Integration Suite: Facilitates rapid, pre-built integration between SAP and non-SAP systems, ensuring a holistic flow of customer and order data.

  • Extensibility: BTP allows for the creation of custom applications (e.g., a bespoke in-store client for associates) that access unified data without disrupting the core business systems.

D. The Intelligence Engine: SAP AI Capabilities

To move beyond consistent service to truly contextual and predictive customer experiences, Artificial Intelligence (AI) is indispensable. SAP embeds AI across its portfolio:

  • SAP CX AI Toolkit: This powers personalisation through solutions like SAP Emarsys, enabling real-time product recommendations, personalised journeys, and optimised content based on unified customer data.

  • Intelligent Automation: SAP AI capabilities in the broader business suite enable predictive inventory management and automated demand forecasting, ensuring that the right product is in the right location to fulfil the promise made by the Commerce Cloud.

Conclusion

The mandate is clear: the market rewards unified, intelligent customer experiences. By leveraging SAP Commerce Cloud, SAP BTP, and the integrated power of SAP Business Suite and its AI capabilities, organisations can move beyond simply managing multiple channels to truly operating as an Intelligent Omni-Channel Enterprise, securing that vital customer loyalty and market growth.

SAP Commerce Cloud SAP HANA Enterprise Cloud SAP BTP, Kyma runtime SAP Commerce #S4HANA #SAPBTP SAP Business Suite #IntelligentEnterprise #CXAIToolkit #AI #BusinessAI Artificial Intelligence

entry.title: Re: Synchronous goods receipt posting for production orde...
entry.content:
Hi @sarah_frueh ,

I know I am answering to old post to avoid confusion, those are looking for solution. Please see the below link for details for step by step approach Solution.

Snippet: 

Synchronous Goods Movement + EWM-QM

  • This is only supported from release S/4HANA 2022, earlier releases contain this as a restriction. QM is supported in synchronous goods movements for Goods Receipt (inspection type 01) and Goods Receipt from Production (inspection type 04) but not for Stock Transfer (inspection type 08).
  • From release S/4HANA 2022, the attachment of the release restriction note contains the information that Quality inspections for synchronous goods receipt postings are supported in Embedded EWM (3218648  SAP S/4HANA 2022: Release information and restrictions for EWM in SAP S/4HANA). Due to system boundaries (use of qRFC and the possibility of the target EWM system being unavailable to book the sync posting) synchronous GM will not be available in Decentral landscape.
  • Synchronous GM works only with IOT4, inspection process 0 – Insp after GR, and with "No inspection rule" setting. 
  • To allow inspection for stocks received via synchronous GM (internal or external procurement) the flag needs to be set under the WH-dependent IOT setting in SPRO:

Details: https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/sewm/4428870892.html?locale=en-US

Kind Regards,

Ajit

entry.title: SAP Business AI中的定制化AI服务概况介绍
entry.content:
如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

 

SAP Business AI中的定制化AI服务是什么？

SAP Business AI中的定制化AI服务是基于BTP开发的，为特定场景提供AI能力的服务集合。

其在SAP AI能力矩阵中连接通用AI能力与具体业务场景

 

SAP为什么要开发定制化AI服务？

客户痛点：

企业面临大量同质化的AI需求，包括重复性手工作业、文档处理效率低下、业务流程缺乏智能化决策支持等挑战。

战略目的：

通过针对性的AI技术在选定场景下重新定义业务流程，实现从传统手工操作向智能化自动处理的转型

功能目的：

将AI能力深度嵌入到具体业务场景中，解决文档处理、业务决策、流程自动化等实际问题

核心价值主张：

让AI技术真正服务于业务，将复杂的AI能力转化为易用的业务解决方案

 

定制化AI服务的核心能力是什么？

核心能力模块

  • Joule Studio：提供低代码/无代码的AI应用开发平台，让业务用户能够快速构建定制化的AI解决方案，无需深度技术背景即可实现AI能力的业务化应用
  • Document AI：专注于文档智能处理，包括文档信息提取、分类识别、业务实体识别等功能，能够自动化处理发票、合同、报告等各类业务文档
  • Business AI Services：提供可复用的AI业务服务，包括实体识别，个性化推荐、翻译服务、票据智能处理等，通过API方式集成到各种业务场景中

 

定制化AI服务和市面上常见的类似产品有什么区别？

功能层面

提供端到端的AI解决方案，从数据处理到模型部署再到业务应用，形成完整的AI服务链条，确保AI能力的实际业务价值实现

平台效应

基于BTP平台搭建，享受统一的身份、安全，数据等服务，降低AI应用的技术复杂度和运维成本

生态协同优势

与SAP业务应用无缝集成，确保AI能力能够直接作用于现有业务流程，实现即插即用的智能化升级

 

定制化AI服务该怎么用呢？

定制化AI服务是基于基础模型，针对指定场景定制化后的产物，所以每个定制化AI服务的能力相对固定，例如：

Document AI可以用于文档信息提取以及自动化工作流；

Joule Studio可以为标准Joule助手添加能力，例如给它去差旅平台为用户订票的Skill技能；

Joule Agents可以为标准Joule助手添加可咨询的业务专家；

Business Entity Recognition可以从文档中识别和分类业务实体，如公司名称、地址、产品代码、金额等关键业务信息，用以自动化工作流

 

总结

SAP 定制化AI服务通过深度的业务场景理解和平台化的技术能力，让AI真正成为企业数字化转型的加速器。

 

关于本文内容有任何问题或见解，欢迎在评论区留下你的想法

entry.title: Hybrid Server-Side Rendering for UI5: Bridging CAP and AI-Generated Views
entry.content:
What if your UI5 views could be generated automatically by AI and pre-rendered on the server before ever reaching the browser? This isn't science fiction, it's an experimental approach I've been developing that combines Cloud Application Programming (CAP) with UI5 server-side rendering and AI-powered view generation.

 

The Core Concept: Hybrid SSR for UI5

Server-side rendering in UI5 doesn't have to mean fully rendering HTML on the server. My approach takes a hybrid path: pre-populating XML views with data on the server using Handlebars templating, while still letting UI5 handle the final rendering on the client.

This creates a practical architecture that addresses two critical concerns in enterprise applications:

  • Enhanced Security: By populating data directly into XML views on the server, you avoid exposing raw OData services to the client. Users receive only XML files with the specific data they need, no access to full OData endpoints through browser debugging tools.
  • Improved Performance: Rather than making separate OData calls for each view, the application receives XML views with data already embedded, reducing round trips and potentially improving load times.

 

From Concept to Reality

I first introduced this concept at reCAP, where I demonstrated how to combine UI5 and CAP to implement server-side pre-rendering of UI5 artifacts. The session covered:

  • Pre-rendering UI5 fragments and views using CAP
  • How these two SAP frameworks can enhance each other's capabilities
  • My approach to implementation and ideas for future improvements

The goal was to show how leveraging UI5 and CAP together can elevate both frameworks to the next level.

Watch the reCAP session: Hybrid UI5 Server-Side Rendering with CAP

 

Taking It Further: AI-Generated Views

At Devtoberfest, I pushed this concept into really exciting territory by adding AI-powered view generation. This is where things get interesting.

How AI Changes Everything

Traditional UI5 development requires developers to manually create XML views for every entity, form, and table in their application. What if AI could do this work for you, not just as a one-time code generator, but dynamically, on every request?

Here's how it works:

  1. AI analyzes your CAP entity definitions - It understands your data model, relationships, field types, and annotations
  2. AI generates appropriate UI5 views - Forms for editing, tables for lists, master-detail layouts, whatever makes sense for your data
  3. Views are pre-rendered on the server with actual data from your OData service
  4. Instant delivery to the client - Pre-populated, ready-to-display views arrive in milliseconds

The Power of On-Demand UI Generation

This approach means your UIs are generated fresh when needed, rather than maintained as static files. Imagine:

  • Zero view maintenance: Change your entity model, and your UI automatically adapts
  • Instant prototyping: From data model to working UI in seconds
  • Smart adaptability: AI can generate different views based on user roles, device types, or business context
  • Automatic best practices: The AI understands your annotations and generates appropriate labels, help text, and validations

Watch the Devtoberfest session: Taking UI5 Server-Side Rendering to the Next Level with AI

 

Get Started: Available Resources

Ready to experiment with this approach? I've made everything available as open-source plugins and a demo application:

CAP Backend Plugin

ui5-cap-serverside-rendering-plugin
Enables server-side rendering capabilities in your CAP backend. Handles Handlebars templating, data population, and view serving.

UI5 Frontend Library

be.wl.serversiderendering.library
The UI5 library that enables client-side handling of server-rendered views, including custom routing and view management.

Complete Demo Application

ui5-cap-serverside-rendering-demo
A fully functional example showing how to integrate both plugins, configure routing, and implement server-side rendering in a real application.

 

Try It Out

This is an ongoing experiment, and I'd love to see what the community builds with these tools. Whether you're interested in the basic SSR approach or the AI integration, the plugins and demo provide everything you need to start experimenting.

entry.title: Re: Deletion of Basic data text in Material is not replic...
entry.content: Hi Mines, Are you using DRF to trigger material replication via IDOCs? Here is the official notes: DRF for material does not support message function ‘003’ (deletion). DRF for material always sends the full material. Solution options: 1. Using only ALE: Sending a segment deletion is supported in standard ALE (transaction BD21). This option doesn’t need additional coding. 2. Using DRF or ALE: This option needs additional coding in the target systems. If it is possible to determine which data gets deleted in the target system, you can also implement the IDoc inbound BAdI IDOC_DATA_MAPPER in the target system. In this BAdI, set the segment’s message function (MSGFN) to ‘003’ (deletion). This enables the IDoc inbound (usually function module IDOC_INPUT_MATMAS01) to delete the data. Br. Thomas

entry.title: Beyond UI5 Controls: Using Web Components Across Frameworks
entry.content:
When building UI5 applications, you need to decide: should you create a classic UI5 Control or use a UI5 Web Component? This question matters even more when your organization uses different frameworks and wants a consistent user experience everywhere.

I recently presented this topic at both UI5con and SAP Devtoberfest 2025, sharing what we learned from integrating custom web components into UI5. This work showed us how to keep a consistent look and feel across applications while going beyond the standard SAP Fiori design.

Watch the full sessions:

  • Devtoberfest 2025 - Beyond UI5 Controls with the Rise of Web Components - Detailed walkthrough with live demo

  • UI5con 2025 - Same Topic, Different Perspective - Original presentation with Q&A

Why Web Components Matter

UI5 controls have always been great for building SAP applications. They give you pre-built components with Fiori design, theming, and internationalization built in. No need to worry about CSS or making things look right.

But things are changing. Many organizations now use Angular, React, Vue, and UI5 across different teams. Web components let you build once and use everywhere. They work with any framework while keeping their style and functionality intact.

This helps organizations:

  • Standardize UI/UX across teams using different frameworks
  • Use company-specific design systems instead of only SAP Fiori
  • Share components between Angular, React, Vue, and UI5 apps
  • Save development time by reusing components

When to Use What?

Use traditional UI5 controls when:

  • Your app only uses UI5
  • You're happy with SAP Fiori design
  • You don't need cross-framework support

Use UI5 web components when:

  • You want Fiori design in non-UI5 frameworks
  • You need components for Angular, React, and Vue
  • You're building a shared component library

Use native web components when:

  • Your company has its own design system
  • You need company branding everywhere
  • You work with different technologies

Our Proof of Concept

We integrated Nova design system web components into a UI5 application. This meant creating proxy controls that connect UI5 to the web components, handling properties, events, and data binding.

Our demo app, a simple To-Do list, replaced standard UI5 controls with Nova web components. Everything still worked like a normal UI5 app. Check out the GitHub repository to see how it works.

What We Learned

Technical stuff:

  • You need proxy controls to connect UI5 with web components
  • Event handling sometimes needs extra code
  • Data binding requires attention, especially with components built differently

Deployment: Web components work fine with SAP BTP. You can keep your consistent UI while using all BTP features.

Current state: Web components work well in production, but the ecosystem is still growing. You might need extra code for some edge cases. It might be early for productive usage 😉

What's Next

Web components are changing how we think about UI development in SAP. Traditional UI5 controls are still great for many cases, but web components give you more options.

As more organizations share their component libraries on npm, we'll see better standardization and teamwork across companies. It's not about picking UI5 or something else, it's about using the right tool for each job.

Whether you're a UI5 developer, an architect planning UI strategy or a consultant helping clients, understanding web components and UI5 integration will be useful.

Resources

  • 📺 Devtoberfest 2025 Session - Watch the full presentation with live demo
  • 📺 UI5con 2025 Session - Original talk with Q&A
  • 💻 Demo Application - GitHub Repository with code examples
  • 📅 Event Page - Devtoberfest event details

entry.title: Re: Automated mass updates for Asset
entry.content:
Dear Aalmayyahi,
To manage multiple physical locations per fixed asset in SAP, the recommended approach is to leverage Functional Locations and/or custom fields with structured hierarchies. SAP does not natively support assigning multiple physical locations to a single FA record, so a flexible design is key.

Following are 4 options to Capture Multiple Physical Locations.

1.Functional Locations (FLOCs) in SAP PM (Plant Maintenance)
Ideal when assets are distributed across multiple operational sites or need maintenance tracking.
Create a hierarchical structure of functional locations (e.g., Building > Floor > Room).
Assign each FA to a primary FLOC; for multiple locations, consider creating sub-assets or equipment records linked to different FLOCs.
This will enables detailed reporting, maintenance planning, and spatial tracking.

2.Sub-Assets
When a single FA card represents multiple physical units.
Create sub-assets under the main asset, each representing a unit at a specific location.
Maintains financial roll-up while allowing location-specific tracking.

3. Custom Fields or User-Defined Fields (UDFs)
When you need to store multiple locations but don’t require full FLOC functionality.
Add custom fields to the asset master record (AS03) or use classification and characteristics to store multiple location tags.
Lightweight and flexible; good for reporting without full PM integration.


4. Asset Master Classification System
For tagging assets with multiple attributes, including locations.
Use class types (e.g., 100 for equipment) and assign characteristics for each location.
Allows multiple values per characteristic and supports advanced reporting.


Hope this will help you
